_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

body:
According to information architect and multimedia journalist Mirko Lorenz, data-driven storytelling is primarily a workflow that consists of the four steps:

  1. Gathering data
  2. Filtering and analysing the data
  3. Visualising the data
  4. Making a story

The value of data increases as it turns into a story. This is why data science and journalism skills must be used cooperatively. Those who work with the data must be able to communicate why it is important or useful, otherwise the value is lost.
displayTitle: The four step data storytelling process
title: The four step data storytelling process

body: At what point of the project should you start to develop the narrative of your story?
title: Q: Planning a project
instruction: Choose an answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: As you are analysing the data
Once you have visualised the data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Framing your narrative before you gather data can help focus the process. Forming a narrative and story at a later stage will mean prior stages of the process are unguided and take longer.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Framing your narrative before you gather data can help focus the whole. Forming a narrative and story at a later stage will mean prior stages of the process are unguided and take longer.

body:
What is the maximum number of tables that you should have on each sheet of a spreadsheet?

Hint: The number of tables per sheet should equal the number of records per row.
title: Q: How many tables per sheet?
instruction: Select one option and then click submit

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

You should only have one table per sheet and one record per row. This will make processing and filtering the data easier. Don't use your spreadsheet to make data look pretty at time of collection, use it to collect accurate data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

You should only have one table per sheet and one record per row. This will make processing and filtering the data easier. Don't use your spreadsheet to make data look pretty at time of collection, use it to collect accurate data.

body: Which of the column titles below would be the most appropriate for the name of a healthcare facility?
displayTitle: Which is the best column title?
title: Q: Which is the best column title?
instruction: Select one answer and click submit

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Be as descriptive as you can with your column titles. Facility name is better than Name as it is specific and clear. You could also expand the title further to Heath care facility name, but if this is clear from the title of the dataset, it may not be necessary.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Be as descriptive as you can with your column titles. Facility name is better than Name as it is specific and clear. You could also expand the title further to Heath care facility name, but if this is clear from the title of the dataset, it may not be necessary.

body: Which feature of a spreadsheet application allows you to keep the column titles visible at all times?
title: Q: Keeping column titles in view
instruction: Select one option and click submit

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The Freeze function allows you to keep certain rows visible even when you scroll through 10,000 rows.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The Freeze function allows you to keep certain rows visible even when you scroll through 10,000 rows.

body: Which data type is best to represent the rating of a facility on a scale of 0-5 stars?
title: Q: Which data type?
instruction: Pick one answer and click submit

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

When recording data that is on a scale, it is best to use numbers which can be easily sorted. Using text such as 1 star limits how the data can be used. Avoid custom datatypes that cannot be not easily sorted (e.g. ★★★).

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

When recording data that is on a scale, it is best to use numbers which can be easily sorted. Using text such as 1 star limits how the data can be used. Avoid custom datatypes that cannot be not easily sorted (e.g. ★★★).

body:
There are three main types of metadata: descriptive metadata, structural metadata and administrative metadata.

Which of the following would be considered administrative metadata?
title: Q: Describing data

_items.text: When and who created an object

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Administrative metadata provides information to help manage a resource, such as when and how it was created, file type and other technical information, and who can access it.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Administrative metadata provides information to help manage a resource, such as when and how it was created, file type and other technical information, and who can access it.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

body:
Standards enable exchange and interaction with multiple systems. For example, a standard gauge railway is 4 ft 8½ inches wide and allows for trains to travel huge distances without their wheels having to be re-spaced for each providers line. 

A standard is critical to ensuring one thing is compatible with another, no matter where in the world it is. They mean that planes can be refuelled at any airport, DVDs read on any DVD player and documents opened on any PC. The latter can be hindered by the need for software from a specific manufacturer to open documents, therefore not all computer formats or standards are open. First then, let's take a look at what open standards are and discover why this might be.
displayTitle: What is a standard and why do we need them?
title: What is a standard and why do we need them?

body: The four step process draws from the field of journalism, but it is equally as relevant in other fields. It is just as important to communicate the results of your analysis, as it is to conduct a sophisticated data analysis. In this module we have explored the four step data storytelling process and the time requirement for each stage.
title: Summary

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

body: You can test what you have learned in this module by correcting a messy spreadsheet, which is this weeks assignment.
title: Summary

body:
Data-cleaning is essential to ensure that when the data is used, the right conclusions are made.

Often errors are not even noticed by data publishers because the data can change over many years. Errors can be the result of human mistakes in data entry, like mistyping or incorrect abbreviations.

Be aware that cleaning may take longer than you think. A careful cleaning process will, however, save substantial time in the long-run.

Follow our data cleaning exercise to get started with Open Refine and discover how easy it is for yourself.

Get started with data cleaning in Open Refine
title: Summary

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

body:
To tell a powerful story you need to be able undertake the majority - if not all - of the stages of data storytelling. Success will depend on understanding the time requirement of each stage in the process.

In this module we will introduce:

  • The four step data storytelling process
  • Components of the four step process
  • Planning your time
displayTitle: A four step approach to storytelling with data
title: A four step approach to storytelling with data

body:
It is important to plan your time carefully in any data project. Follow these steps to help you plan efficiently.

The 80:20 rule for data storytelling

Gathering, organising, filtering and cleaning of data will take 80% of your time. Done right this can significantly reduce the time you spend in the analysis and visualisation.

Develop your narrative at the beginning

Much like research has a hypothesis to test from the start, it's useful to spend the first stages of a project outlining the audience and narrative. This will help keep the data collection focused and time to a minimum.
title: Planning your time

body: This course has been specifically designed to look at the entire process of using data to tell stories. Explore the components below to get an overview on how the course fits together.
displayTitle: Components of the four step process
title: Components of the four step process

_items.title: 1. Gathering data
_items.body:
In order to use data, you first need to have the data. 

Finding data can be easy, if you know where to look. However the web also contains a lot of hidden data. Find out more in the gathering data module. 

When you are gathering data, is it important to understand your legal rights to use the data. The next module covers some of the key legal information you need to know.

_items.title: 2. Filtering data
_items.body:
The four step process outlined above assumes that once you have data, you can immediately start filtering and using it. 

There are however several steps preceding the filtering of data:

Organising data

Data is likely to be gathered from many sources and it will be necessary to organise the data in a consistent way for analysis. 

Cleaning data

As you start to organise the data you are likely to note errors or inconsistencies in the data that require fixing. 

Filtering data

Once you have a usable dataset, it is finally possible to start filtering the data to find your story.

_items.title: 3. Visualising data
_items.body:
Once you have analysed the data, the next step is to visualise the data to highlight significant findings.

When it comes to visualising data, you need to consider three things:

Format: Which visualisation should you choose?

Clarity: Does the visualisation tell your story?

Intrigue: Does the visualisation engage or deceive?

_items.title: 4. Telling a story
_items.body:
In order to maximise impact of your story, you need a strong narrative which can relate to the desired audience at the right time. 

Find out more on writing your own narrative with the final module of this course.

displayTitle: Are you ready to start the four step process?
title: Are you ready to start the four step process?

body: Which part of the data storytelling process is of most value to the public?
title: Q: Where is the value?
instruction: Choose an answer, then click 'Submit'

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The story is the most valuable part of the data storytelling process. It is the story which brings the data and visualisation together with a compelling narrative.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The story is the most valuable part of the data storytelling process. It is the story which brings the data and visualisation together with a compelling narrative.

body: While gathering data, what is the most important thing to check?
title: Q: Checking your data
instruction: Choose an answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Your rights to use the data
The potential to visualise the data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

When gathering data is it important to know your rights to use the data (find out more in the next module). If you cannot use the data, then checking the quality or suitability for visualisation is simply a waste of your time.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

When gathering data is it important to know your rights to use the data (find out more in the next module). If you cannot use the data, then checking the quality or suitability for visualisation is simply a waste of your time.

body:
A common challenge in ensuring data quality is difficulties people face when using spreadsheets. When data is properly managed, it is much easier to answer fundamental questions and conduct analysis. Correctly managed data also ensures you aren't making decisions based on faulty evidence. Knowing how to structure and organise data in a spreadsheet is fundamental to ensuring consistency in your data. 

In this module we look at how to effectively structure a spreadsheet for raw data collection. We will cover:

  • Spreadsheet layouts
  • Column titles 
  • Header rows and the freeze function
  • Data types

At the end of this module you can try out what you've learnt on a spreadsheet.
title: Organising data

body:
Effective organisation and careful management of data makes it easier to ensure data quality, and analyse or visualise results. The first step is understanding the basics of a spreadsheet and creating a good template in which to collect data. 

Discover the fundamentals of spreadsheet layouts below.
title: Spreadsheet layouts
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Rows, columns and values
_items.body:
Ensure you understand these important aspects and use them correctly.

Rows: A row represents a single record in your collection. For example in a dataset of companies, each row must represent a single company and in a dataset of health facilities, each row must only represent a single facility. 

Columns: A column defines a feature (or field) for every record. For example in a dataset of people a good field to collect would be "first name".

Values: Values are what is recorded in each row/column. For example "Emily" would be the value for the "first name" of a single person in a dataset of people.

_items.title: Sheets and multiple sheets
_items.body:
Each sheet in a spreadsheet should only contain one table.

Start your table at row 1, column 1 (top left corner).

Avoid adding multiple tables starting in different parts of the sheet (e.g. column L row 16).

You should also avoid using multiple sheets unless it is necessary to collect multiple different datasets in one spreadsheet. 

For example, if you are collecting a dataset of companies, add them all to a single sheet and avoid dividing them by type or location of company. You may end up with a sheet containing many thousands of rows, however it is easier to filter a single sheet than multiple sheets.

Module 7 looks at filtering data in a spreadsheet in more detail.

body:
Column titles are essential to ensuring that data can be collected and used correctly.

Keep your column titles clear, concise and relevant to the dataset. Avoid using acronyms or other abbreviations, as they can be confusing.

If you are collecting numbers in your data, don't forget to define the units and be as clear as possible in the description. For example: "Cost ($millions)" would be a clearer title than "Cost" or "Cost ($m)".

Make sure your column titles are only contained in a single row – preferably the first row in the spreadsheet, starting at A,1.
title: Perfect column titles

body:
The freeze function is useful when viewing, managing and organising large datasets. It 'freezes' the column titles at the top of the page, so you can always check your value against the associated row and column, without scrolling back up to the top. 

This function can be accessed from the 'View' menu of most spreadsheet applications.
displayTitle: Header rows and the freeze function
title: Header rows and the freeze function

body:
Values contained in a single column should be consistent in their type. For example, in a First name column you would use text, an Age column would contain numbers, a Date of birth should contain dates.  

When collecting data, ensure that all your entries are expressed in the same type of value. For example if you have an age column, you should change any text entries to numbers to make sure they match up. In the majority of spreadsheet applications you can enforce the criteria of the data type per column by going to 'Validation' from the 'Data' button in the menu.
title: Data types
instruction: Explore each data type below

_items.title: Text/string
_items.body:
This data type is the most flexible and allows any combination of characters to make a sentence.

e.g. Emily, 2nd Royal Artillery

_items.title: Numbers
_items.body: Numbers can include whole numbers (otherwise known as 'integers') such as 1, 12, 312 etc, or decimal numbers, such as 1.25, 32.789. Be careful with the UK decimal point (2.5) and the European decimal point (2,5).

_items.title: Date
_items.body:
Picking a consistent format for dates is crucial. You can choose how you want to display it (e.g. 2016-09-14) or use the one built into the spreadsheet application. 

As dates can be presented in many different ways, it is recommended that you validate them (check for correctness and consistency) on collection by going to 'Data' in the menu bar and choosing 'Validation'. However, this does not always work if the American form (MM/DD/YYYY) and European form (DD/MM/YYYY) are used interchangeably - it would be impossible to determine whether the date '04/05/2016' would mean the fourth of May, or fifth of April.

_items.title: Defined options
_items.body:
Data types can also be defined options, such as true or false, yes or no, or a limited range of text or numbers. 

You can use the validation function to ensure that a user can only enter valid values.

displayTitle: Are you ready to organise your data correctly?
title: Are you ready to organise your data correctly?

body:
Although your data may be adequately managed, often a raw dataset can be riddled with errors. Errors are often not even noticed by data publishers because the data can change over time. In other cases, errors can be the result of human mistakes in data entry, like typos or incorrect abbreviations.

When working with any data, it is important to know how to find errors and correct them to make the data more useful.

In this module we'll explore the following:

  • Common data errors
  • Useful data cleaning tools
  • Benefits of cleaning data
title: How to clean your data

body: ODI Trainer David Tarrant explains why clean open data is important, how to clean open data you find and what tools are available to support you.
title: Data cleaning – in 2 minutes
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

body:
Knowing that your data is clean is important to ensure you have a reliable starting point when using a dataset and creating new value from it.

Clean data is data that is consistent, free from duplication and ready for machine consumption.

If data is clean, it is easier to combine with different datasets and find deeper insights.
displayTitle: What do we mean by clean data?
title: What do we mean by clean data?

body: There are a number of common errors in data that you should look out for in any dataset you are working with.
title: Common errors in data
instruction: Click the headings to explore further.

_items.title: Wrong date formats
_items.body:
Dates can be written in inconsistent ways. Mixed date formats are sometimes simple to spot:

8-sep-2013 vs 8/9/2013

and sometimes less obvious:

8/9/2013 vs 9/8/2013.

Another challenge is that some applications, like Excel, will ‘guess’ the format when a dataset is opened, which can hide how dates are actually written in the file.

The most common error is the mixed use of American (MM/DD/YYYY) and European (DD/MM/YYYY) formats.

_items.title: Multiple representations
_items.body:
People often try to save time when entering data by abbreviating terms. If these abbreviations are not consistent, it can cause errors in the dataset.

Differences in capitalisation, spacing and genders of adjectives can all cause errors.

_items.title: Duplicate records
_items.body: A duplicate record is where the same piece of data has been entered more than once. Duplicate records often occur when datasets have been combined or because it was not known there was already an entry.

_items.title: Redundant data
_items.body:
Redundant data is anything that is not relevant to your work with the dataset. Often a dataset has been created for a specific purpose which requires details you may not need.

Common occurrences of redundant data include rows that represent total amounts.

Other times columns of data have been combined or replicated in order to assist human readability.

_items.title: Mixed numerical scales
_items.body:
Numerical values in datasets often use different scales to make it easier for a human to read. In budget datasets, for example, the units are often in the millions. 1,200,000 often becomes 1.2m. However, smaller amounts like 800,000 are still written in full. For a machine, this means they read the larger figure as 1.2, which causes errors.

Be careful with the UK decimal point (2.5) and the European decimal point (2,5).

_items.title: Mixed ranges
_items.body: Data is sometimes measured in ranges, such as age or salary range. In order for a machine to understand these ranges it is important to separate the high and low values.

_items.title: Spelling errors
_items.body:
Spelling errors are often difficult to identify in tabular data.

Don’t forget to run your data through a spell-checker to catch spelling errors.

body: Without clean data, we can’t build information. There are a number of useful tools that can help the process of cleaning data.
title: The data-cleaning toolkit
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.
mobileInstruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: The data-cleaning toolkit
_items.body:
When you are looking for errors in data, it may be necessary to download and upload datasets in many tools for cleaning and processing.

It is also important to keep a note of what changes have been made and share these openly with others so that everyone can benefit from your work, particularly if the data you are cleaning is existing open data that has been published.

In this section we look at two of the main tools and their uses:

  • Open Refine
  • Excel and similar spreadsheet programmes

_items.title: Open Refine
_items.body:
Open Refine is a software tool designed to deal with uncleaned data. The tool is a column-based browser that allows you to fix errors across an entire open dataset in a single action. The errors that can be fixed include:

  • Date formats
  • Multiple representations
  • Duplicate records
  • Redundant data
  • Mixed numerical scales
  • Mixed ranges

_items.title: Spreadsheet programmes
_items.body:
Open Refine is a key tool for cleaning data. However, it is sometimes easier to fix some errors in a spreadsheet programme:

  • Spelling errors
  • Redundant data
  • Numerical verification
  • Fixing shifted data

body: In addition to the tools that can be used to clean open data, it is important to understand the benefits that cleaning brings.
displayTitle: What are the benefits of cleaning data?
title: What are the benefits of cleaning data?
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.
mobileInstruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Prioritise cleaning
_items.body:
If data is not clean then decisions made on the basis of it could be wrong. This can affect products or insights you develop from data and, in some cases, have an impact upon thousands or even millions of people.

A recent study found that the process of preparing data for analysis can take anywhere between 60% and 80% of the time of a data-driven project.

_items.title: Enhance usability
_items.body:
Sharing a clean open dataset will make the data more usable. Tools like Open Refine allow you to share change history, letting people know what has been cleaned and how. Making the process open as well as the data adds to the sustainability and trust a user can put in a dataset.

There are also data-cleaning communities emerging that could be supported more actively, such as OpenStreetMap communities.

Take me to OSM Denmark Community Wiki

_items.title: Discover insights
_items.body:
Many data-cleaning tools, including Open Refine, help you to combine and enrich datasets. This can lead to valuable insights being discovered.

For example, enriching a dataset that refers to businesses (by name or some other identifier) can inform you if the business is still trading and its current financial position.

Get started with enriching data.

body: Can you recall the reasons why data needs to be cleaned, the useful tools to use and which common errors you should look for in datasets?
displayTitle: Are you ready to clean data?
title: Are you ready to clean data?

body: Uncleaned open data is a problem because:
displayTitle: Why does data need to be cleaned?
title: Q: Why does data need to be cleaned?
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: it cannot be plotted on a chart
it can lead to wrong conclusions

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Unclean data is a problem because it can result in the wrong conclusions being made. This should not prevent the publication or use of the data, however cleaning is an essential part of the process.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Unclean data is a problem because it can result in the wrong conclusions being made. This should not prevent the publication or use of the data, however cleaning is an essential part of the process.

body: Which of these pairs of tools are the most useful for cleaning data?
displayTitle: What are two of the most useful tools for cleaning data?

instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Open Refine and Excel (or equivalent spreadsheet editors) are two of the most useful tools for cleaning open data

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open Refine and Excel (or equivalent spreadsheet editors) are two of the most useful tools for cleaning open data

body: Which of the following are errors in data that require cleaning?
title: Q: Recognising errors
instruction: Choose three answers and click 'Submit'

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Mixed use of scales, redundant data and multiple representations of the same data are just some of the errors that need to be fixed in unclean data. While the granularity and lack of licence are a problem, they are not related to the data itself being unclean

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Mixed use of scales, redundant data and multiple representations of the same data are just some of the errors that need to be fixed in unclean data. While the granularity and lack of licence are a problem, they are not related to the data itself being unclean

body: In any given data-driven project, how much time can be spent cleaning and preparing data?
displayTitle: How much time can be spent cleaning and preparing data?
title: Q: How much time can be spent cleaning and preparing data?
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Evidence suggests that between 60% and 80% of a data project's time will be spent cleaning, transforming and preparing data for analysis.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Evidence suggests that between 60% and 80% of a data project's time will be spent cleaning, transforming and preparing data for analysis.

body:
Describing and annotating datasets provides an opportunity for data to be better understood across borders and sectors. Adding detail can help with discovery, access, retrieval, organisation and understanding. In this module, we will look at what data annotation is and how it can be applied to different types of data.

This module will cover:

  • what is data annotation?
  • why annotate data?
  • what is describing data?
  • why describe data?
  • best practices for annotating and describing data
title: Annotating and describing data

body:
Describing and annotating datasets provides an opportunity for data to be better understood across borders and sectors. Adding detail provides an opportunity to help with discovery, access, retrieval, organisation and understanding.

When annotating or describing data, it is best to use existing, widely used and supported standards and vocabularies.
title: Summary

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

body:
An 'annotation' traditionally refers to a comment or explanation added to text or a diagram. Annotations traditionally appear in the margin of a book or as highlighted within text itself.

Crucially, an annotation is separate to content itself and is added to help explain, emphasise or comment on something. Annotations are added to specific parts of the original content or data, not the whole.

In data, annotation is used to aid with visual presentation (e.g. on web pages), define types and languages of data (e.g. to distinguish between US and British date formats) and to provide comment in source control systems.
title: What is data annotation?

body: Data annotation assists with the presentation, definition and description of parts of data. Explore how each is used below.
title: Why annotate data?

_items.title: Presenting data
_items.body:
Markup languages like XML and HTML annotate text in a way that is syntactically distinguishable from that text.

They can be used to add information about the desired visual presentation or machine-readable semantic information.

For example, the <em> tag in HTML is used to emphasise a block of text.

_items.title: Defining data
_items.body:
One of the key roles of annotation in data is to help define data types and formats. 

Date formats and timezones are key examples. These data formats could vary, depending on the geographic location of the person doing the data entry.

Annotating the date with aspects such as format and timezone can help both presentation and re-use of the data. 

This type of annotation is commonly used in data schemas. You can discover more about date and timezone data types in XML here.

_items.title: Providing comment
_items.body:
Much like writing in the margin of a book, there are systems that allow data and other digital resources to be commented on. 

Track-changes and version-control systems (such as GIT) are the most widely used. Along with allowing comment, these systems allow the comments and questions to be collaborated on; both also track who it was that commented and/or fixed the problem and when it took place, allowing a history to be viewed.

body:
When adding a description of a whole dataset, it is often useful to add metadata (data about data). Like annotations, metadata exists after or beyond the main content, hence the use of Greek proposition 'meta', which means 'after' or 'beyond'. Unlike an annotation, however, metadata primarily describes the whole of the dataset or object e.g. the publisher of a book.

There are three main types of metadata (source):
title: What is describing data?

_items.title: Descriptive metadata
_items.body: Descriptive metadata describes a resource for purposes such as discovery and identification. It can include elements such as title, abstract, author and keywords.

_items.title: Structural metadata
_items.body: Structural metadata is data about containers of data. It indicates how compound objects are put together – how pages are ordered to form chapters, for example.

_items.title: Administrative metadata
_items.body: Administrative metadata provides information to help manage a resource, such as when and how it was created, its file type and other technical information, and who can access it.

body: Metadata plays a key role in three key areas.
title: Why describe data?

_items.title: Facilitating discovery
_items.body:
With it roots in library catalogues, metadata has always been about discovery. 

Using metadata to help describe items is not just about knowing the title, abstract and author. Adding genre or other classification data can help ease the discovery of related newer (or older) material on the same subject. 

On the web, metadata helps search engines index content from across the web. Careful management of your metadata will help with the discovery of your carefully curated content.

_items.title: Providing context
_items.body:
In addition to general descriptive metadata, adding further contextual data and references to related content can help place one item or dataset amongst others. 

For example, in photographs, often metadata is added pertaining to where the photo was taken, on which camera and with which lens.

On the web, related items can be linked with the <link> annotation, helping reference another book on the shelf. 

In data, it might be useful to outline how the data was collected and when it should and shouldn't be used.

_items.title: Controlling usage
_items.body:
Physical libraries can control book the use of books with who is allowed in the door, but controlling access is more challenging with digital resources on the web. 

Providing metadata containing rights statements and licenses is of critical importance, both for machine and human use of data. 

The use of such metadata is exemplified on sites such as Flickr. Using the advanced search you can filter photos that can be modified and used commercially.

body: Data annotation is...
title: Q: What is data annotation?
instruction: Select your answer and click 'submit'

_items.text: separate to the content itself and is added to assist explanation
a means of expanding the content

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The key concept of an annotation is that it is separate to the content itself and is added to assist explanation, emphasise a particular aspect or to provide comment. Annotations are added to specific parts of the original content or data, not the whole, thus they are not metadata.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

An annotation is separate to the content itself and is added to help explain or emphasise a particular aspect, or to provide comment. Annotations are added to specific parts of the original content or data, not the whole, and are therefore not metadata.

body: Annotating data helps...
title: Q: Why annotate data?
instruction: Select up to three answers and click 'Submit'

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Data annotation helps define, present and provide comment on parts of the data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Data annotation helps define, present and provide comment on parts of the data.

body: When annotating or describing data, it is best to use existing, widely used and supported standards and vocabularies. Some that are closely related to data are listed below.
displayTitle: Best practices for annotating and describing data
title: Best practices for annotating and describing data

_items.title: Data schema
_items.body:
When publishing data, providing a schema will help the user understand how the data is organised and what value the data contains. 

A schema is basically a description of the column headings (or titles) in a dataset and a definition of the type of data that is contained within each defined column.

Many data representation languages have related schemas:

  • XML Schema
  • JSON Schema

It is also useful to note that you can validate a simple CSV file using a JSON schema. Why not try this out at CSVLint.io?

_items.title: Dublin Core
_items.body:
The Dublin Core Schema is a small set of vocabulary terms that can be used to describe web resources (video, images, web pages, etc), physical resources such as books or CDs, and objects such as artworks.

The original Dublin Core Metadata Element Set consists of 15 metadata elements including title, creator, type, format, source and rights.

Dublin Core is now widely used in library catalogue systems.

Read more about Dublin Core on Wikipedia.

_items.title: Data Catalog vocabulary
_items.body:
The Data Catalog Vocabulary (DCAT) defines a standard way to publish machine-readable metadata about a dataset.

DCAT has been designed to compliment Dublin Core and extend it to enable the specific description of a dataset rather than just resources in general. 

The Open Data Institute has produced a useful guide on how to mark up your dataset with DCAT.

_items.title: Open Data Rights Statement vocabulary
_items.body:
Data published to the web should always be accompanied by machine-readable metadata that describes the dataset, its means of creation and, importantly, a statement of the rights that relate to its potential use.

A clear statement of rights can ensure that data users fully understand the potential for use of a dataset, whether it is suitable for their purposes, and any obligations that may incur through using the data.

The ODRS vocabulary is based on describing the relationships between three types of resource: datasets, rights statements and licences.

The Open Data Institute provides both a publishers and users guide to the Open Data Rights Statement vocabulary.

displayTitle: Are you ready to annotate and describe your data?
title: Are you ready to annotate and describe your data?

body: When annotating or describing data it is best to use existing, widely used and supported standards and vocabularies. Match each one to its usage below.
title: Q: Best practices

_options.text: Provides a description of the column headings
Provides metadata
Provides re-use information
Provides a description of the column headings
Provides metadata
Provides re-use information
Provides a description of the column headings
Provides metadata
Provides re-use information

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

A schema provides a definition of the data. Dublin Core is a vocabulary of metadata terms that can be used to describe resources. The ODRS vocabulary provides a statement of re-use rights.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

A schema provides a definition of the data. Dublin Core is a vocabulary of metadata terms that can be used to describe resources. The ODRS vocabulary provides a statement of re-use rights.

body:
Open data and open standards are very closely related, both in definition and application. This module examines what open standards are and why they are important for open data.

This module looks at:

  • What is a standard and why do we need them
  • What is an open standard
  • The types of open standard
  • Open standards and open data
title: Open data and open standards

body:
If open data is data that anyone can access, use and share, then it would be logical for an open standard tpo be a standard that anyone can access, use and share.

This should be correct, but an open approach to standards setting can also mean that the development of the standard in the first place is open and collaborative. Some organisations, such as the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) classify 'open standards' as those that can be adopted without payment of royalty fees. While other standards bodies, such as the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF), International Organization for Standardization (ISO), International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC), and ITU-T, allow royalty fees to be charged.

These different interpretations mean open standards can be complex, especially when standards definitions themselves may be copyrighted but still allow the standard to be broadly used and implemented.
title: What is an open standard?

body: There are many types of open standard. Explore some of them below
title: The types of open standard

_items.title: Open formats
_items.body:
An open format is a file format for storing digital data, defined by a published specification usually maintained by a standards organisation. It can usually be used and implemented by anyone.

An open format can be implemented by both proprietary and free and open-source software, using typical software licences used by each.

By contrast to open formats, closed formats are considered trade secrets and cannot be implemented by anyone.

_items.title: Open data schema
_items.body:
The term 'data schema' refers to the organisation of data as a blueprint for how the data is constructed and organised. A schema may also define a number of formulas or integrity constraints imposed on the data. 

An 'open schema' allows others to use this blueprint to create their own data, which may then be easily combined and analysed.

_items.title: Open identifiers
_items.body:
Identifiers are at the heart of how data can be effectively published, retrieved, reused and linked.

They cover everything from postcodes and country codes to company numbers and ISBNs for books. 

Open identifiers can be used by anyone in their own data to ensure it can be reused and linked to other data. 

Data increases in value the more it is connected, so open identifiers are critical to maximising value without having restrictive licensing get in the way.

_items.title: Open interfaces
_items.body:
An open interface can be connected to by any device without restriction.

At home, we have plug sockets and lighting circuits that can connect to any number of devices – there are international standards related to everything from wiring colours to current. 

In the world of data, an open interface (or public API) is an interface that does the same for machines. It allows anyone a data endpoint or machine interface without restriction. 

Currently, the Internet of Things has many competing and proprietary standards, meaning that not all smart light bulbs can interface with every smart switch. (Not so smart, you might say.)

_graphic.attribution: Photoroyalty - Freepik.com [CC-BY]

displayTitle: Are you ready for open standards?
title: Are you ready for open standards?

body:
Open data and open standards are very closely related, both in definition and application.

Closed and proprietary formats, schemas, identifiers and interfaces reduce use and compatibility with other data. This results in data being of less value than it otherwise would be.

Open data and open standards go hand in hand and ensure that value can be maximised for all. They provide a level playing field on which everyone can build for the benefit of all.
title: Summary

body:
Without open standards, you might not have open data.

For example, data that is only made available in a closed format cannot be said to be open as only those who have access to the format specification can manipulate (i.e. use) the data. Additionally while the data might be open, if the schema is not open then it may be impossible to interpret the data and if the data is changed then you may invalidate the terms of use of that schema, e.g. by using it on your own data. Likewise for identifiers, some data cannot be made open as the identifiers are not licenced openly and this has profound knock on effects when we are not allowed to identify things in the public sector, like addresses. Finally, without open interfaces, the access to data might be restricted, stopping the integration with key services. Imagine if you had to have a different size power plug for everything in your house because there was no open standard interface? 

Open data and open standards go hand in hand and ensure that value can be maximised for all. They provide a level playing field on which everyone can build for everyones benefit.
title: Open data and open standards

body: Standards are useful because...
title: Q: Why do we need standards?

_items.text: railway gauges are standardised at 4 ft 8.5 inches

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Standards are critical to ensure one thing is compatible with another no matter where in the world that thing is. They mean that planes can be refuelled at any airport, DVDs read on any DVD player and documents can be opened on any PC.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Standards are critical to ensure one thing is compatible with another no matter where in the world that thing is. They mean that planes can be refuelled at any airport, DVDs read on any DVD player and documents can be opened on any PC.

body: An open standard should be...
title: Q: What is an open standard?
instruction: Select two answers, then click 'Submit'.

_items.text: available for anyone to implement and use.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Whilst there are a few different definitions of an open standard, it should be built collaboratively and be made available for anyone to implement and use.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Whilst there are a few different definitions of an open standard, it should be built collaboratively and be made available for anyone to implement and use.

body: In this module we explored four types of open standards, but why are they beneficial?
title: Q: Types of open standards
instruction: Match each heading to its benefit, then click 'Submit'.

_options.text: can be used and implemented by anyone without the need for specific software
reduce the risk of malware and computer viruses.
make higher profit margins for their developers.
ensure maximum compatibility as data is collected following the same structure.
enables anyone to open the file format.
makes the data good quality
increases the value of data through linking to other datasets
include ISBNs and postcodes.
help users add context to data
encourages competing and proprietary standards
allows anyone to interact with a data endpoint or interface without restriction.
facilitates data analysis

_feedback.correct:
That's right

Open formats can be used and implemented by anyone without the need for specific software.

Open data schema ensure maximum compatibility was data is collected following the same structure or blueprint.

Open identifiers increase the value of data through linking to other datasets.

Open interfaces allows anyone to interact with a data endpoint or interface without restriction.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open formats can be used and implemented by anyone without the need for specific software.

Open data schema ensure maximum compatibility was data is collected following the same structure or blueprint.

Open identifiers increase the value of data through linking to other datasets.

Open interfaces allows anyone to interact with a data endpoint or interface without restriction.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

body:
Schemas play a key role in enabling the wide, automated re-use of data. This module looks at the role of and importance of schemas in assisting reusability and quality of data.

In this module we explore:

  • What is a schema?
  • Why do schemas matter?
  • Schemas in practice
  • Choosing or designing schemas
title: Choosing and designing schemas

body:
Open data needs to be simple for anyone to use, whether for a new app, scrutiny, analytics, research or simply to gain a deeper understanding of a subject.

The greatest use comes when the same type of data is consistent across different publishers. An application that tells you where local toilets are should be able to work everywhere, not just in one town. Consistency is also important because it allows you to combine and compare your data with that of other authorities for internal use or sharing.

An important part of making data consistent is to use the same schema to define the structure and blueprint of the data.
title: Why do schemas matter?

body: All different data structures tablular, hierarchical and network can have schemas applied to them. Explore each below and how they apply to a number of different data formats.
title: Schemas in practice

_items.title: Tabular data schemas
_items.body:
A schema for tabular data will define the column titles (keys) and valid values that can be contained in each column. 

In desktop applications like excel, column titles can be simply created through typing them in the top row of the sheet. The problem with this is they can be changed and this is the reason many workbooks use data entry forms to stop the schema being changed. 

The data validation function in excel can enforce rules on what valid values can exist and even allow the selection from a pre-defined list of values. 

A slight issue with excel is that data portability is not very easy as the schema and validations rules cannot be exported from an Excel file and applied to another dataset. 

FirstName

LastName

Instrument

DateOfBirth

John

LennonVocal1940-10-09

Paul

McCartneyBass Guitar1942-06-18

George

HarrisonGuitar1943-02-25

Ringo

StarrDrums1940-07-07

_items.title: XML Schema Definition (XSD)
_items.body:
It is possible to import a schema into Excel, however these have to be defined in the eXtensible Markup Language (XML) format and conform to the XML Schema Definition (XSD) standard.

XML is a hierarchical file format and thus can be challenging to implement for tabular data. 

The example below shows part of the schema definition for the tabular data shown previously. The full schema can be downloaded here. 

Such schema can be used but machines to automatically validate the structure and contents of a datasets. One key advantage of XSD schemas is that they can used with a wide variety tabular and hierarchical data formats. Why not try using the schema from above with an online validation tool against the same data in XML.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

_items.title: JSON Schema
_items.body:
XSD provides a good specification for schema definitions, however XML is challenging to create and use. The JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) schema format provides a much simpler alternative which is easier to create.

Additionally unlike XML, JSON is also natively supported by the Javascript programme language which is used widely on the web. This means it is much more effluent to use and does not require complex parsers to translate from one format to another. 

Shown here is the JSON schema for our tabular data file. Try if for yourself by downloading the tabular data (in CSV) and schema (in JSON) and then using csvlint (a tabular data validator) to validate that the data conforms to the schema. 

Note that XSD is still a far more developed schema definition than JSON schema. As can be seen from this example JSON schema does not have a way to validate the range of inputs currently.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

displayTitle: Ready to take advantage of schemas?
title: Ready to take advantage of schemas?

body: Which of the following should a schema define?
title: Q: Key features of a schema
instruction: Pick you answer and then click 'submit'

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

A schema defines column/key titles in the data as well as value types and constraints such as ranges for value values.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

A schema defines column/key titles in the data as well as value types and constraints such as ranges for value values.

body: What key benefit do schemas provide?
title: Q: Why do schemas matter?
instruction: Select you answer and click 'submit'

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Schemas help ensure that the same type of data is consistent across different publishers. Essentially they are talking the same language.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Schemas help ensure that the same type of data is consistent across different publishers. Essentially they are talking the same language.

body: When collecting a new set of data what should you do first?
title: Q: Choosing schemas

_items.text: Research and build upon existing schemas
Collect some data, don't worry about schema

_feedback.correct:
That's Right!

The best choice when structuring a dataset is an existing standard schema. Using a standard schema ensures data can be instantly combined with that of other publishers.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The best choice when structuring a dataset is an existing standard schema. Using a standard schema ensures data can be instantly combined with that of other publishers.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

body:
Schemas play a key role in enabling the wide and automated re-use of data. A schema is a blueprint for data that defines a set of integrity constraints and rules relating to the structure and contents of a data resource. 

The greatest benefit comes when the same type of data is consistent across different publishers, something that schemas enable. 

The best choice when structuring a dataset is an existing standard schema. Using a standard schema ensures data can be instantly combined with that of other publishers. 

There are challenges in using schemas with existing data collection tools, particularly excel however their use should be carefully considered by data controllers.
title: Summary

body: The choice (or design) of schema for dataset is a major factor in how useful your data will be to others, both humans and machines. Using existing and widely adopted schemas both helps others use your data and ensures that you can use data from others.
title: Choosing and designing schemas

_items.title: Using an existing schema
_items.body:
The best choice when structuring a dataset is an existing standard schema. Using a standard schema ensures data can be instantly combined with that of other publishers. 

Many data controllers already have a well defined set of supported schema and using them could be as simple as simply renaming some column titles.

In other cases it might be necessary to change the values in data to conform to the schema, e.g. ensuring that units of measurement and date formats match the requirement of the schema.

_items.title: Creating a new schema
_items.body:
No common schema for the dataset you are publishing?

Before creating a new one, why not find out whether there is already some consensus among an existing community of users somewhere (for this, use your favourite search engine).

You might need to contribute a new schema but there may be an opportunity to get the community to help.

body:
A schema is a blueprint for data that defines a set of integrity constraints and rules relating to the structure and contents of a data resource. 

The schema will define a number of key things:
title: What is a schema?

_items.title: Column/Key titles in the data
_items.body:
Defining a consistent set of column titles (or keys) for a data set is essential to ensure that datasets of the same type can be merged and analysed easily. 

Often column titles will change or be abbreviated to save time however this causes a lot of problems when analysing data over long periods of time. 

Adding column titles is less of a problem but has to be taken into account when analysing data.

_items.title: Value types
_items.body:
With the column title/keys defined it is important to define the valid data type for the values, e.g. number, text, date, co-ordinate etc. 

This will help with a simple datatype validation.

_items.title: Value contrainsts
_items.body:
With the value type defined, valid constraints such as being required, need to be unique, being in a certain unit (e.g. Gallons (UK)) or be within a certain range should be defined. 

For example a column might be entitled "Cost (£m)"; thus any values should be numbers (without commas).

Setting a valid range also help avoid and explain any errors in the data. For example setting a range of 0.001-100 on the "Cost (£m)" (if it is known that cost cannot exceed £100m).

Range validation stops people accidentally misreading the column title/units and entering 100000000 instead of 100 for £100m.

body:
When it comes to open data formats, start with CSV.

A comma separated values (CSV) file is simply lines of data, with each data point separated from the next by a comma. CSV is perfect for tabular data and can be easily loaded into and saved from applications like Excel, making it accessible to users.

Although CSV doesn’t maintain formatting and graphs like Excel formats, it is an open, machine-readable format. CSV represents the simplest format that still supports broad reuse of open data. In other words, CSV is the ‘lowest common denominator’ for open data – open data should be made available in this format wherever possible?
displayTitle: Choosing the right format for open data
title: Choosing the right format for open data

body:
The 'format' of a dataset refers to the way in which the data is structured and made available for humans and machines.

Choosing the right format helps ensure the data can by simply managed and reused. To maximise reuse of data, it may be necessary for a publisher to use a number of formats and structures available across different platforms to suit users' needs.

In this module we'll explore the following:

  • Why formats matter to data
  • Choosing the correct structure
  • Accessing different open data formats
  • Keeping it simple with CSV
title: Data formats and structures

body: It is important to pick the right format to...
displayTitle: Why is it important to pick the right format?
title: Q: Why is it important to pick the right format?
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Picking the correct formats will assist usability, make management easier and lower the barriers of access. Choices here will not affect privacy and may even increase cost

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Picking the correct formats will assist usability, make management easier and lower the barriers of access. Choices here will not affect privacy and may even increase cost.

body: Which data structure would you use for the data in the picture?
displayTitle: Which data structure would you use for the data in the picture?
title: Q: Which data structure would you use for the data in the picture?
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

The picture shows that relationships between data points are important. These relationships are all 'parent-child' relationships, meaning that a hierarchical structure is ideal.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The picture shows that relationships between data points are important. These relationships are all 'parent-child' relationships, meaning that a hierarchical structure is ideal.

body: What format should open data be made available in wherever possible?
displayTitle: In which format should open data be made available wherever possible?
title: Q: In which format should open data be made available wherever possible?
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

The comma separated values (CSV) format is a simple to understand, highly reusable format. It is also open for anyone to write new tools to interpret it. The other formats are useful but not as widely adopted for data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The comma separated values (CSV) format is a simple to understand, highly reusable format. It is also open for anyone to write new tools to interpret it. The other formats are useful but not as widely adopted for data.

body: ODI Trainer David Tarrant explains why formats matter in open data, how to choose the right structure and formats, and why CSV is a good starting point for most tabular open data.
title: Open data formats
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

body:
As a user of open data, it is important to understand how publishers are delivering different formats to you for reuse.

Not all data is suitable for download either because it is too large, too regularly updated or too complex to expose as static files. Some data may need to be split into smaller parts. Other data may need to be published as live feeds to make sure it stays up-to-date.
displayTitle: Finding open data in the right formats
title: Finding open data in the right formats
instruction: Click the headings to explore further.

_items.title: Downloadable open data
_items.body:
Tabular data is the best suited for download. This is why most government open data portals are predominantly tabular data. However, managing millions of rows of data may need other considerations:

  • Should the data be split into smaller datasets?
  • How often should the data be updated?
  • How will changes in the way you publish affect the previous releases?

_items.title: Live data and data feeds
_items.body:
Some data is not suitable to be made available as a downloadable file.

Much of this data is updated so regularly that the file downloads would be too large for most users. This type of open data structure may be made available by a machine interface, also know as an application programming interface (API).

There are many services that make machine interfaces available over the Web. These services can be directly integrated into other Web applications. For an example of an open data API, see at the Belgian railway company.
Take me to iRail API

body:
Geospatial data is often more complex than simple tabular datasets.

It can exist as a hierarchical dataset, detailing countries and counties/states, or as a network dataset, detailing roads.

When publishing this type of data, formats like geoJSON (based upon JavaScript Object Notation - JSON) and KML (based upon Extensible Markup Language - XML) should be considered.

These formats are specifically designed with usability in mind and can easily be imported and exported from specialist mapping tools like Open Street Map and CartoDB.
title: Geospatial open data formats

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]
Ing Andrej Kaprinay [Shutterstock standard licence]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

body: Test your knowledge on open data formats with our questions. Can you recall the important points?
title: Are your formats in order?

body: Open data must be available for anyone to access, use and share. In this section we consider what formats maximise the usability of data, ease of access for users and simple management for publishers.
title: Usability, management and access
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more

_items.title: Usability
_items.body:
The most usable format for data is likely to be one in which the dataset was first created. In many cases, this format may be a proprietary software programme like Microsoft Excel. While such programmes often have the ability to export data in other formats, their popularity can make publishing in a different format a barrier to reuse by others.

Software programmes like Excel also come with richer content, such as styling on tables and graphs of data. These can all help to give context to a human who is trying to understand the data.

_items.title: Management
_items.body:
For some publishers, open data is now the main source for their data, even for staff in the publishing organisation. Using open data as a way for staff to access information inside an organisation has many benefits:

  • It increases knowledge of open data within the team.
  • It increases sustainability and trust in the data, by making it a key component of the organisation’s operations.
  • It creates clear opportunities for innovation.

_items.title: Access
_items.body:
For open data to be as accessible as possible, it must be:

  • In a format that the user can understand.
  • A format that machines can read.
  • In a format that supports the data's easy reuse.
  • In a format that doesn’t require expensive tools to access.

The format appropriate for each dataset may be different. A document (like a PDF) may make the data easy for a human to understand but not the most readable for a machine. For this reason, accessibility is often achieved by making the same data available in a range of different formats.

body: Not all data can be appropriately expressed as a spreadsheet. Different file formats may have to be considered. There are three key structures to be aware of: tabular, hierarchical and network.
title: Common data structures
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more

_items.title: Tabular
_items.body:
The most common structure for data is tabular. Data is organised into rows and columns listing sequential values, such as expenditure.

If the data is based on separate entries that are not linked to each other then a tabular file structure in a format such as CSV is ideal. An example of appropriate tabular data is the Italian data portal’s museum attendance figures.
Take me to Italian Data Portal

_items.title: Hierarchical
_items.body:
Hierarchical data shows the relationships between data points, such as a family tree or municipalities in each country. If the dataset depends on the relationship between data points and follows a structure in which data points are linked in vertical ‘trees’, a hierarchical data structure in a format such as JSON is ideal. An example of appropriate hierarchical data is this JSON file from json.org
Take me to the json.org example

_items.title: Network
_items.body:
Network structured data allows relationships to exist between any combination of elements in any direction.

A good example of a network data structure is a social network. Think of your network of friends and their friends on Facebook; consider first, second and third degree contacts on LinkedIn.

 

The Web is another example of a network data structure, where webpages link to any number of other pages in any direction.

body:
The 'format' of an open dataset refers to the way in which the data is structured and made available for humans and machines.

Choosing the right format helps ensure the data can by simply managed and reused. To maximise reuse of the data, it may be necessary for a publisher to use a number of formats and structures available across different platforms to suit users' needs.

Wherever possible, the CSV file format should be used for sharing open data. CSV is a simple to understand, highly reusable and machine-readable format.
title: Summary
